There is a saying amongst seasoned litigators with respect to expert witnesses that "you don't need an expert to tell you which way the wind blows." This folksy axiom comes in handy when things are too odd or when things are too ordinary, because there is no need to have an expert tell you what you already can determine on your own.

There will be those who debate recent weather events, but what is obvious when one looks at the multitude of surprisingly extraordinary and large-scale events occurring worldwide and especially in the Northern polar regions (arctic oscillation), coupled with the measurably massive additional energy which is being added to the oceans, ice, and atmosphere, that we are beginning to see the consequences of excessive greenhouse gases. Who put them there will recede in importance as larger scale events begin to play out.

What is particularly sad is that we have waited too long to take necessary mitigative action, and from here on out things are on autopilot toward the more extreme, more variable, and more surprising. There is no "off" switch. Indeed, there is no "slow down" switch.

"Buckle up," I say to those environmentalists who wish to save or preserve their little slice of paradise, be it desert, view, windy vista, species, plot of land, or whatever you specially value as against all else, we are entering the whirlpool and this time Noah is not at the helm.

"Contingent mitigation" of CO2 emissions makes almost no sense.  The long term committed climate change is bigger than the transient warming you see over fifty years by a factor that is probably 1.5 to 2, but is almost impossible to project in advance from monitoring the climate (a point I made in my AGU Early Warning Systems talk last fall).  So, by the time you see something catastrophic coming round the bend, you are already committed to a lot more warming to come, so (short of equally dangerous monkeying with Earth's albedo) what do you do at that point?  Even dropping CO2 instantaneously to zero by instantaneously replacing all fossil fuel plants by nuclear won't undo the damage, because the CO2 in the atmosphere will continue to have an almost unabated impact on climate for the following thousand years.  The only "contingent mitigation" strategy that could conceivably make sense would be having a backup plan to scrub CO2 out of the atmosphere, and certainly more research on that is needed.  However, it is so difficult to do this economically that it's highly uncertain whether any workable air capture scheme will come along in time, and be deployable at scale fast enough, to do anything like "contingent mitigation."  I don't see any value in that concept.  The technology of keeping CO2 out of the air to begin with is far more workable and economic than any kind of air capture likely in the forseeable future.  The idea of "contingent mitigation" just holds out a false hope.

"True, higher taxes aren’t popular, but neither are cuts in government programs. So we should add to the roster of fundamentally unserious people anyone who talks about the deficit — as most of our prominent deficit scolds do — - as if it were purely a spending issue."

Well said. Every time conservatives start talking about making "hard choices" and how "the math doesn't add up" I feel like my ears will start to bleed. How incredibly disingenuous to peddle in self-righteous rhetoric about how liberals want to defy arithmetic when conservatives themselves have no intention of making any "hard choices." That would imply they have problems with slashing away at programs for children, the poor, and the disadvantaged. But clearly this makes them lose little sleep at night. The choice is actually quite easy.

Republicans' own insistence on balancing the budget points directly to the logical implementation of tax hikes. I don't know what is more distressing - the politicians who so deliberately say the opposite of what they mean, or the public who fails by and large to see how absurd the idea of balancing the budget purely through slashing spending is.

We have to thank Speaker Boehner for putting the House budget proposal in perspective. When a reporter asked him the other day about his job-killing budget plan, Boehner said, "If some of those jobs are lost, so be it." Tough luck. Amen. Dana Milbank of the Washington Post writes that about 650,000 government jobs would be lost under the House budget plan & 325,000 indirect support jobs would go, too." I call the House plan the The Million-Man Unemployment Budget.

Of course, Boehner isn't as callous as he sounds. He did back a proposal to build F-15 engines in his home state of Ohio, even tho Defense Secretary Robert Gates had said repeatedly the engines were superfluous. Bad news for Boehner: the House voted down the F-15 engines. Boehner sure doesn't have much control over his caucus. So be it. Tough luck. Amen.

And Boehner tried to pretend those government & collateral jobs his budget would eliminate were the 200,000 jobs President Obama had added to the federal work force. The truth, according to several sources, including PolitiFact, is closer to 20,000 jobs added, and most of those are in security & military personnel -- areas that Republicans won't touch. Mike Hall of the AFL-CIO writes that "on a per capita basis (federal employees per 1,000 Americans), [the federal payroll is now] at the lowest level at least since 1962."

The "intellectual" Paul Ryan is not above making stuff up, either. He said this week of President Obama's budget proposal: "What we have is $1.6 trillion in new tax increases, $8.7 trillion in new spending. He's going to be adding $13 trillion to the debt over the course of his budget." But fact-checker Glenn Kessler of the Washington Post says of Ryan's fuzzy math, "It's bad enough to toss around 10-year figures. And Obama could be faulted for not submitting a budget that gets federal government spending back to the 20.3 percent of the gross domestic product. But to demand that he meet a standard no modern president has ever met -- and then label it as 'new spending' -- is highly misleading."

The House isn't the only place where Republican play fast and loose with the numbers. I'd give the crown to Sen. Jeff Sessions. He complained on the teevee that President Obama's budget wasn't serious because it would only reduce the deficit by $1.3 trillion over the next ten years. Then he went on another show and said the House budget was great because it reduced the federal deficit by $1 trillion over the next ten years. That is, a Republican budget that reduces the deficit significantly less, and primarily on the backs of the poor and middle-class, is WAY better than a Democratic budget that -- for the most part -- finds savings elsewhere.

No, I'm not giving President Obama a pass on cutting home-heating subsidies & Pell grants. And I'm perfectly aware that Obama's game is to let Republicans hang themselves, then "compromise" with other cuts that will hurt poor- and middle-class families. As Jon Stewart says, all of the proposed cuts by both the House & the President are to programs that Democratic voters like.

But still. So far, there's only one grown-up in the game, and he's the President.

For far too long, America has been living in a dream world, concocted by partisan talking points, with the complicity of the media, often ignoring the overarching implications of the short-term decisions we make as a society. Perhaps this allowed us to function in the past, when information flowed slowly, when commerce could not occur around the globe at the touch of a key, but this is the 21st century. The only thing that will carry the day is truth and reality.

If we remain complacent by letting others defend what we believe, without becoming involved in the pursuit for a better tomorrow, then the fault is ours. We have nothing to fear except giving in.

Our money system, as I understand it, is based on the idea of trust - not only in the trust in an individual, or a business, or an industry or country - but in the trust that the future will be better than the present. Productivity increases, value increases, efficiencies increase, and society arrives in a better place.

The world is constantly changing, faster now than at any point in recent memory. The uprisings in the Arab world - uprisings arriving not out of hate, but of the desire for the simple, universal rights of man - should be the clearest example that our world has evolved at a better day, but let us not leave it at that. Our technology has increased to a point where an idea can spread around the world in an instant - anyone's idea. The only challenge in spreading that idea is our collective agreement that that idea is right.

Harnessing this innovation is of the utmost importance for business and society. The old ways of doing things allowed for inefficiencies to be hidden, covered up, ignored, or taking advantage of - that doesn't have to be the case in the 21st century. Government and business can run far more effectively, we just need to start down that path, providing each of us an opportunity to be participants in our global system of commerce, while using those same principles to improve each of our lives, in a manner we choose.

Our societies best days are ahead of us, we only need the courage to pursue those ends, despite the constant ocean of noise coming from those bent on defending the safety and familiarity of the status quo. The only ones we will have to blame if the future we fear arrives is ourselves.

Talk about cutting the deficit when there is a huge output gap and about 20% of workers are either looking for work, have taken work beneath what they are qualified to do, or have just given up looking is crazy-talk. Macro 101: the government balance, private domestic balance, and current account balance have to sum to zero as an accounting identity. When the country is running a current account deficit and the private domestic sector is saving/delevering, then the government deficit must compensate for this demand leakage in order to increase spending power enough to purchase what the economy is capable of producing. If the deficit is too small for this, then the output gap will not close and unemployment will persist.

The lost opportunity resulting from failure to do this is enormous and this loss cannot be recaptured. Add to it the degradation of resources, especially human resources, and it becomes clear that not acting through fiscal policy is insane.

Trying to "save money" by cutting the deficit will just result in larger deficits due to reduced tax revenue and increased welfare payments (automatic stabilizers). The deficit hawkery is just politics to undermine the president and Democratic Party. Shame, shame, shame. And the deficit dovery is political expedience instead of telling the people the truth. More shame.
